statement: Understanding Recurrent Ascites. Recurrent ascites is characterized by repeated accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity. Symptoms may include abdominal distension, discomfort, and shortness of breath.
What Are Your Treatment Options?. Compare your options for managing recurrent ascites.
Large Volume Paracentesis. Large volume paracentesis (LVP) involves insertion of a needle into the peritoneal cavity to drain excess fluid and provide temporary relief from recurrent ascites.
Large Volume Paracentesis. Outpatient procedure performed in a hospital
Large Volume Paracentesis. Repetitive procedure required whenever fluid builds up impairing QoL
Large Volume Paracentesis. Up to 97 mins required per drainage
Diuretics. Diuretics are medications that increase excretion of sodium and water, aiming to achieve a negative sodium balance and reduce fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity.
Diuretics. Oral administration, especially for ascites from liver cirrhosis (requires careful assessment of kidney function, risk of hypovolemia, and ototoxicity)
Diuretics. Administered once or twice daily
Diuretics. Regular monitoring required for electrolyte imbalance or kidney damage

Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. An indwelling peritoneal catheter is a long-term option for managing recurrent ascites, allowing patients to drain excess fluid at home. This supports greater independence and improved quality of life.
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. One-time outpatient procedure to place catheter
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Fewer hospitalization days improving QoL
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Drainage performed at home
Large Volume Paracentesis. Procedure Setting | Column: Outpatient or hospital-based procedure | Content:
Diuretics. Procedure Setting | Column: Prescribed after assessment of body weight, fluid status, renal function and electrolytes | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Procedure Setting | Column: One-time outpatient catheter insertion | Content:
Large Volume Paracentesis. Frequency of Use | Column: Requires repeated procedures each time fluid reaccumulates | Content:
Diuretics. Frequency of Use | Column: Daily, long-term therapy | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Frequency of Use | Column: Repeated drainage at home as needed | Content:
Large Volume Paracentesis. Hospital Visits | Column: Hospital/clinic visits each time fluid builds up | Content:
Diuretics. Hospital Visits | Column: Regular monitoring of electrolytes & kidney function | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Hospital Visits | Column: Hospital visits not required once catheter in place | Content:
Large Volume Paracentesis. Cost | Column: - Procedure cost - Cost of multiple hospital admissions | Content:
Diuretics. Cost | Column: - Medication cost - Medical supervision cost | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Cost | Column: - Procedure cost for catheter insertion - Drainage bottle cost | Content:
Large Volume Paracentesis. Invasiveness | Column: Minimally invasive bedside procedure | Content:
Diuretics. Invasiveness | Column: Non-invasive (oral medication) | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Invasiveness | Column: Minimally invasive insertion | Content:
Large Volume Paracentesis. Pain or Side Effects | Column: Hypotension, wound infection, leakage of fluid at the needle insertion site | Content:
Diuretics. Pain or Side Effects | Column: Electrolyte imbalances, dehydration, hypotension, ototoxicity, renal dysfunction | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Pain or Side Effects | Column: Infection and catheter blockage | Content:
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Minimally invasive placement: A small tube is inserted through a tiny abdomen incision during a simple outpatient procedure.
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Simple home drainage: When fluid builds up, connect the tube to a vacuum bottle. Each session takes 5-15 minutes.
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Continuous symptom control: Drain fluid at home, reducing hospital visits and improving comfort.
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 100% catheter placement success
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 76% had no hospital visits due to catheter-related complications.
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. 83% to 100% of patients enjoyed relief from ascites symptoms.
Indwelling Peritoneal Catheter. Infection rate as low as 6%.
The catheter is inserted in the abdomen for draining ascites.
The protective dressing is virtually undetectable under clothing.
